awd_titl_txt: UNS: Collaborative Research: Numerical and Experimental Study of the Instability Mechanisms and Bubble Growth due to Explosive Boiling
awd_abstract_narration:
1512093 / 1511152
Esmaeeli, Asghar / Hermanson, James C. 

The proposal aims to provide much needed insight of the very rapid, explosive vapor bubble growth much like those in boiling water but even faster.  This can occur by properly providing and focusing energy on liquids.  One potential application of this knowledge is that, since the bubble comes into existence and grows fast while at micro-scales, it can help design micro-scale actuators commonly used in small devices.  Both undergraduate and graduate will be involved in, while K-12 students and their teachers will also be exposed to, the research.

The PIs propose a combined experimental and modeling approach to (1) determine the range of parameters over which explosive boiling in quiescent flows will occur and, under this condition, (2) to gain fundamental understanding of the dynamic growth of a single vapor nucleus, and (3) to explore the dynamics of multi-nuclei growth.  Current research in the field is almost exclusively experimental in nature, and many crucial aspects cannot be probed quantitatively due to the complexity of experimentation.  The numerical modeling will facilitate interpreting experimental results, which will be acquired using high-speed imaging, yielding much-needed quantitative insights and helping to solve problems over a broader range of engineering problems involving rapid evaporation.  If the bubble growth dynamics is captured, it can be used as an actuator by properly focusing energy onto its initial growth that occurs at micro-scales. The results can improve understanding of energy focusing phenomena at the micro-scale involving bubbles as actuators if successful.  Similarly, it will help to improve the design of flash-boiling atomizers and the processes involving transport and storage of volatile liquids or large scale energy generation.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY

por.por_cntn:
Direct Numerical Simulations were performed to study unstable growth of a vapor seed in a pool of superheated liquid, using a front-tracking/finite-difference scheme. The momentum and mass conservation equations were solved in the framework of one-fluid formulation, while a sharp interface method was used to solve the thermal energy equation, to explicitly set the temperature of the phase boundary. The computational domain was a cubic box that was sufficiently large so that the domain confinement would not affect the bubble growth. Inflow/outflow boundary conditions were imposed on the velocity and temperature field to maintain an isotropic growth. The computations were performed in the diffusion-controlled growth regime, where the interfacial temperature gradient in the superheated liquid was the main driver for the bubble growth. The methodology and the code were validated by comparing our results with the available benchmark analytical solutions and companion experimental results of our collaborators at the University of Washington.

The working fluids corresponded to water, diethyl ether, and cryogenic-type fluids, and depending on the fluid system, the pressure varied from the atmospheric pressure to several orders of magnitude higher and the vapor seed size varied from a micrometer scale to a millimeter scale. The analysis, however, was performed on a nondimensional ground. Here, the Jacob number (the ratio of the sensible heat over the latent heat) emerged as the key parameter in demarking the unstable growth from the stable. At low to intermediate Jacob numbers, representative of low to moderate superheats, the vapor seed grew isotropically and its growth could be characterized by the analytical correlations pertaining to the diffusion-controlled growth. Here, the bubble surface remained smooth. Beyond a critical Jacob number, on the other hand, protrusions were developed on the surface of the bubble whose growth rate was higher than that of the vapor seed. As a result, the surface of the bubble became wrinkled over the time, leading to a dramatic increase in the evaporative mass flux. Whereas the average radii defined based on the bubble volume and surface area were essentially the same for stable bubbles growing with a smooth surface, the latter was substantially higher than the former for bubbles undergoing unstable growth. To explore the instability mechanism, several different instability models for spherical interfaces were examined.

The results of parametric studies showed that the Jacob number along with the liquid to vapor density and conductivity ratios were the major parameters affecting the growth rate of the bubble itself, with the growth rate correlating positively with these three parameters. The effect of the deviation of the interface temperature from the saturation temperature (corresponding to the system pressure) on the bubble growth rate was studied, using a comprehensive equation. It was shown that in the range of the parameters that were studied here, this effect was minor.

Fundamental studies involving boiling flows are currently limited to stable growth. This research advances our current understanding of the dynamic of rapid evaporation processes and their underlying mechanisms. The evaporative mass flux-driven instability observed here finds applications in other phenomena such as reactive flows. From the technological standpoint, this research may impact the design, as well as operating conditions of processes involving transport and storage of volatile fluids or large-scale energy generation. The study also finds application in flash-boiling atomizers and micro-explosion of emulsified liquid fuel drops to promote combustion efficiency.

This collaborative effort between the Southern Illinois University (Carbondale) and Washington University to date has resulted in several conference presentations and training of three graduate and two undergraduate students.


Last Modified: 01/01/2022
Modified by: Asghar Esmaeeli
